title: 113_s2552
content: The Act titled "Medicare Advantage Participant Bill of Rights Act of 2014" limits the removal of Medicare Advantage providers by MA organizations. The "Medicare Advantage Participant Bill of Rights Act of 2014" limits MA organizations from removing providers from MA plans without cause starting in 2015. The Secretary can remove a provider or supplier from a network if they are medically negligent, violate legal or contractual requirements, or are otherwise unfit to furnish items and services according to the requirements of the title. An MA organization offering an MA plan cannot remove a provider from their network based on cost considerations, starting from plan year 2015. The Secretary can only remove a provider if they are medically negligent, violate legal or contractual requirements, or are unfit to provide services. An MA organization offering an MA plan can only remove a provider from their network for specified reasons before 60 days prior to the annual coordinated election period. The removal must follow a fair notice and appeal process established by the Secretary. The MA organization must provide an explanation to the provider and the Secretary for any removal from their network. The fair notice and appeal process must be followed for removals occurring on or after the effective date specified in a final rule. Under section 422.202(a) of title 42, Code of Federal Regulations, the process for termination or suspension of a provider contract applies to removals from an MA plan network. Participant notice of provider removal must be given at least 60 days in advance. Notification of provider removal from an MA plan network must be given at least 60 days in advance to individuals enrolled in the plan. The notification should include names and contact information of in-network providers offering similar services. The notification of provider removal from an MA plan network must be given at least 60 days in advance to individuals enrolled in the plan. It should include information on options for continuing treatment with similar providers, customer service numbers for network changes. The MA organization must provide advance notice of provider removal from the network to enrolled individuals, including in the annual notice of change for the upcoming plan year. Continuity of care requirements must be met for individuals affected by provider removal. Beginning with plan year 2016, MA organizations offering MA plans must provide transparency in the measures used to establish or modify provider networks. Providers have the right to decline participation in an MA plan network. Beginning with plan year 2016, MA organizations offering MA plans must provide transparency in the measures used to establish or modify provider networks. This includes information on quality and efficiency measures, methodology, and sample size. Providers have the right to decline participation in an MA plan network. The Secretary requires additional information for establishing or modifying provider networks in MA plans, with limitations on sharing identifiable provider information. Sanctions are imposed for noncompliance with specified sections. Beginning in 2015, network access adequacy standards will be enforced for MA plans under section 1852(d)(1) of the Social Security Act. Sanctions will apply for noncompliance with certain sections, including 1852(d)(7) and 1852(d)(8). Amendments are made to Title XVIII of the Social Security Act regarding sanctions and network access adequacy. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will seek input from various groups for Medicare Advantage Plan Compare Tool. Measures will be taken to consider preferences and utilization needs of individuals by September 30, 2015.
